subject: placement: rewrite AllocationCandidates.get_by_filters
commit_message:
placement: rewrite AllocationCandidates.get_by_filters

Using the AggregatedProviderSummaryList object to implement it.

The whole process underlayer as below:
* Get a list of resource provider ids, those resource provider satisfy
  the request sources if it has. If the resource provider proviers all
  the request resources and satisfy the amount, it will be in the list.
  If resource provider providers part of request resources and satisfy
  the amount will be in the list also, will figure out whether this
  resource provider can share resource from other resource provider.
* Populate the usages based on that list of resource provider ids
* Populate the traits based on that list of resource provider ids
* Construct the a list of ProviderSummay objects based on those provider
* Building the mapping between shared and non-shared resource providers
  as AggregatedProviderSummary object.
* Filter out the AggregatedProviderSummay object doesn't have all the
  requested resources based on the resource class id.
* Generate the AllocationRequest and ProviderSummay object from the
  AggregatedProviderSummay object.

subject: Add AggregatedProviderSummary and AggregatedProviderSummaryList objects

Add AggregatedProviderSummary and AggregatedProviderSummaryList objects

"AggregatedProviderSummaryList.get_all_with_any_resource" method will
generate a list of AggregatedProviderSummary objects based on a plain
list of ProviderSummary objects. The main goal of AggregatedProviderSummary
List object is generating the mapping of shared and non-shared resource provider.
Grouping the shared and non-shared resource provider together as an
AggregatedProviderSummary object.

So each of AggregatedProviderSummary object can be a single resource provider
which provides all the requested resources. It also can be a list of
resource providers which provides all the requested resources, those
resource providers are in the same aggregate.

The AggregatedProviderSummary hides the detail of shared or non-shared
provider. Using the AggregatedProviderSummary.has_resources method to
detect whether the provider or providers in the AggregatedProviderSummay
object can satisfy.

subject: Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock
commit_message:
Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock

If system time is adjusted first forward and then backward while a
masakari-engine service is running, then the periodic tasks stops
for the duration of time the system clock was adjusted backward.

This was supposed to be fixed by the following patch to oslo.service
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/286838/ , but the order of imports
in unit tests and production code is different, so masakari services
end up starting with the default eventlet hub, that does not use a
monotonic clock and, thus, is affected by changes of system time.

Testing the change done in the patch is problematic, as it's a
subject of imports order and is not reproduced in functional or
unit tests (oslo_service is always imported earlier than eventlet
hub is initialized, so it just does "the right thing").
The alternative is to make an assertion when services start.

commit_message:
Intel Fortville Dynamic Device Personalization (DDP)

Within Intel Fortville version 6, a new feature was introduced: Fortville
Dynamic Device Personalization (DDP) [1]_ to program an analyzer or parser
via AdminQ. A profile can be used to update FVL configuration tables via
MMIO configuration space; this profile is not microcode or firmware itself.

This spec proposes to add a new method to read from the libvirt driver the
DDP loaded profile in a network device. This new parameter will be added
to `LibvirtConfigNodeDevicePciCap` to extend the PCI NIC information.

The present feature plans to use the existing API, amending the reported
profile string to the NIC capabilities string list. Users will request
capabilities and a specific profile using the same string list in the
Neutron binding profile.

subject: Remove unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from ironic-api
commit_message:
Remove unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from ironic-api

Many moons ago, we thought that we would implement rolling upgrades
using a similar model to nova. This included adding an instance
of an IronicObjectIndirectionAPI to the ironic-api service. What
it was meant to do was for ironic-api to invoke it if it received
an IronicObject that it didn't know what to do with (because it
didn't recognize that object's version). That API would have
invoked the conductor service, asking it to generate a version
of that object which ironic-api would understood.

To use this mechanism, the assumption is that the conductor is
the gateway to the DB.

This mechanism doesn't work for ironic for a few reasons:
- ironic API reads (and occasionally) writes directly to the database.
  We don't want to change it to get access to the DB via the
  conductor all the time, since for e.g. we don't want to slow down
  the conductor
- Nova's rolling upgrade process is to initially take down all their
  conductor services (which handles their DB interactions) at the
  same time,  while their other services are still running. Unless
  ironic changes to have a similar model, we cannot take down all
  the conductor services at the same time if ironic is to provide
  services during a rolling upgrade.

Thus, this patch removes the unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from
the ironic-api service. Note that the IronicObjectIndrectionAPI
class itself (in ironic/objects/indirection.py) was left, in case
things ever change in the future. (And because removing that would
involve touching most, if not all, of the files in the objects/
subdirectory.)

Change-Id: I1aa264a8619105939968c0b8128b358badf00210
Closes-Bug: #1586320

subject: VolumeManager: Check available capacity before creating resources
commit_message:
VolumeManager: Check available capacity before creating resources

For some resources, due to their inheritance of the 'host' attribute
from the source where they are asked to create from, the 'CREATE'
request doesn't go through Cinder scheduler, thus missing the chance to
check if the storage backend still have capacity.  Such resources are
snapshots, volume clones and potentially volume replication clones.  In
some cases, current implementation is fine because those new resource
would end up being in 'error' state if backend is out of capacity, but
in the case where thin-provisioning is desired and the backend has
max over-subscription ratio set, this might cause backend to serve more
than it should if the backend doesn't enforce simliar checks.

This change adds a capacity check in Volume Manager or its corresponding
taskflow before manager calls the backend driver to create the resource.

An alternative solution is the simply passing all create request to
scheduler even for those resource has known 'host'.  It'll be
implemented in separate change for comparison.

Closes-bug: #1537166

subject: Move check_ha_state_for_router() into notification code
commit_message:
Move check_ha_state_for_router() into notification code

As soon as we call router_info.initialize(), we could
possibly try and process a router.  If it is HA, and
we have not fully initialized the HA port or keepalived
manager, we could trigger an exception.

Move the call to check_ha_state_for_router() into the
update notification code so it's done after the router
has been created.  Updated the functional tests for this
since the unit tests are now invalid.

Also added a retry counter to the RouterUpdate object so
the l3-agent code will stop re-enqueuing the same update
in an infinite loop.  We will delete the router if the
limit is reached.

Finally, have the L3 HA code verify that ha_port and
keepalived_manager objects are valid during deletion since
there is no need to do additional work if they are not.

Conflicts:
      neutron/agent/l3/agent.py

Change-Id: Iae65305cbc04b7af482032ddf06b6f2162a9c862

commit_message:
Normalize sorting

The idea behind this patch is to disable default sorting for inner
listing operation, because it's not requred there, and leave it
only for api calls.

With this patch we also remove two unnecessary auxiliary functions from
db api: _get_collection_sorted_by_time and _get_collection_sorted_by_name.
Currently they are used to specify default parameters for 'sort_keys',
but unfortunately they do it wrong, which leads to confusion and
incorrect behavior of the system, when _get_collection_sorted_by_name
is used to sort by time [1], when mutable is passed as a default
parameter value and then modified in the code[2][3] (this is one of the
most famous python anti-patterns [4]).

To cope with non-determinism in tests instead of assertEqual method we use
_assert_single_item, which allows to check results regardless of their
order.

Therefore, the patch allows to increase the performance of Mistral and make
the code cleaner.

[3] https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/stable/pike/mistral/db/v2/sqlalchemy/api.py#L183-L184

subject: Fix adjusted_free_virtual in CapacityFilter
commit_message:
Fix adjusted_free_virtual in CapacityFilter

There are two ways to calculate adjusted_free_virtual
in CapacityFilter.

Take mosr as backend_state.max_over_subscription_ratio

adjusted_free_virtual1 = free * mosr
= (total - used - reserved*total)*mosr
= total(1-reserved)*mosr - used*mosr:
eg:  total = 1TB
     reserved = 0
     mosr = 2
     provisioned = 1TB
     used = 0TB
     free = total - used - total*reserved = 1TB
     adjusted_free_virtual1 = 1TB(1-0)*2 - 0 = 2TB
because of used = 0, when a lot of volume to be creating,
they all see 1TB adjusted_free_virtual.

adjusted_free_virtual2 = cinder.utils.calculate_virtual_free_capacity
= total*mosr - provisioned - reserved*mosr
= total(1-reserved)*mosr - provisioned:
eg:  total = 1TB
     reserved = 0
     mosr = 2
     provisioned = 1TB
     used = 1TB
     free = total - free - total*reserved = 1TB - 1TB - 0= 0
     adjusted_free_virtual2 = 1TB(1-0)*2 - 1TB = 1TB > 0 = free
but there are no space left on the pool or backend.

For provisioned > used*mosr,
    adjusted_free_virtual1 > adjusted_free_virtual2.
For provisioned < used*mosr,
    adjusted_free_virtual1 < adjusted_free_virtual2.
For provisioned = used*mosr,
    adjusted_free_virtual1 = adjusted_free_virtual2.

adjusted_free_virtual = min(adjusted_free_virtual1, adjusted_free_virtual2)
will solve above problems.

Change-Id: I82e1ad675b2b8639ed6696fb49cb9bc3cb55e29a
Closes-Bug: #1719568

subject: Test alloc candidates with same RC in cn & shared
commit_message:
Test alloc candidates with same RC in cn & shared

This change set adds a couple of failing test cases that demonstrate
holes in the design of GET /allocation_candidates when inventory from
the same resource class is present on both the compute node (the "main"
resource provider) and a shared resource provider.

The example being used is where the compute node has some local disk,
and is also associated with a shared storage pool.  Both the compute
node RP and the shared storage RP will provide inventory of DISK_GB.

Test case test_common_rc demonstrates bug #1724613: when I ask for
DISK_GB in this setup, the shared storage pool is ignored.  I expect to
get two candidates back: one with the storage from the compute node; the
other with the storage from the shared storage pool.  But I actually
only get the former candidate back.

Test case test_common_rc_traits_split shows bug #1724633: that placement
can't tell which traits are supposed to apply to which resources.  In
the above scenario, if the local storage is SSD and the shared storage
is RAID, and I ask for SSD + RAID, I "expect" to get back no hits.  But
I would in fact get back a candidate with the storage from the shared
storage pool, because the cumulative set of traits would satisfy my
requested SSD + RAID.

Note that the two tests are functionally identical (traits are ignored
entirely) until https://review.openstack.org/#/c/479766/ lands.  At that
point, depending on how we decide to implement the code that would deal
with this scenario, the test may fail *differently* until bug #1724613
is fixed.

subject: Fix tempest scenario tests waiters
commit_message:
Fix tempest scenario tests waiters

Cleanups for resources such as listeners, pools and health monitors are
currently using a waiter named _wait_for_load_balancer_status to get an
indication that the cleanup process ended successfully.

Because of the way that waiter is currently used in those cleanups,
it's basically just checking that the load balancer state is:
provisioning_status='ACTIVE'
operating_status='ONLINE'

This is not a good measure for the success of a cleanup for the
aforementioned resources since the deletion process of those simply has
no effect on either loadbalancer provisioning_status or
operating_status. Thus, this is not a good indicator.

This creates issues on high load test deployments.
For example: test_listener_basic is a scenario that deletes a listener
and verifies the absence of the load balancing functionality via
_check_load_balancing_after_deleting_resources.
In case the listener deletion is still undergoing (and currently it
does not have a good indication for that), the load balancer will
accept the traffic and fail the test.

The suggestion solution here is not to use _wait_for_load_balancer_status
as an indicator, but rather add waiters to check specifically if a given
resource got deleted or not.

Change-Id: Ib2e4c60e2db28f1345665c2f5859e8f5fde75bc0

commit_message:
use new payload objects for *_INIT callbacks

Part of the work we did while rehoming the callback modules introduced
the notion of payload objects [1] to replace the unstructured kwargs
used today. When using payloads event sources need to use publish()
rather than notify() to trigger the callback(s) and pass along a payload
object (if needed).

This patch begins to move us onto the payload objects by updating
BEFORE_INIT and AFTER_INIT event types to use the payloads.
